Ernest Hemingway

American journalist, novelist, short-story writer, and sportsman

A photo of Ernest Hemingway at work

Here's a time line of Ernest Hemingway's life

  • 1899 - Born in Oak Park, Illinois
  • 1913 to 1917 - Hemingway attended Oak Park and River Forest High School. He took part in a number of sports such as boxing, track and field, water polo, and football. He excelled in English classes, and with his sister Marcelline, performed in the school orchestra for two years
  • 1918 - after applying to serve with, and being turned down by, the US Army, Navy and Marines because of poor eyesight, Hemingway responded to a Red Cross recruitment effort in Kansas City and signed on to become an ambulance driver in Italy. He left New York in May and arrived in Paris as the city was under bombardment from German artillery. By June, he was at the Italian Front
  • 1919 - returned home; moved to Chicago and Toronto shortly after and eventually settled down in Paris
  • 1926 - Wrote "The Torrents of Spring" and "The Sun Also Rises"
  • 1929 - Wrote "A Farewell to Arms"
  • 1937 - Hemingway agreed to report on the Spanish Civil War for the North American Newspaper Alliance (NANA), also wrote "To Have and Have Not" in the same year
  • 1939 - Hemingway crossed to Cuba in his boat to live in the Hotel Ambos Mundos in Havana
  • 1940 - Wrote "For Whom the Bell Tolls"
  • 1950 - Wrote "Across the River and into the Trees"
  • 1952 - Wrote "The Old Man and the Sea"
  • 1953 - Received Pulitzer Prize for Fiction
  • 1954 - Received Nobel Prize in Literature
  • 1959 - He bought a house in Ketchum, Idaho, where he spent last couple years of his life
  • 1961 - Died at age of 61 in Ketchum, Idaho

“There is nothing noble in being superior to your fellow man; true nobility is being superior to your former self.” ― Ernest Hemingway

If you want to know more about this incredible writer you can red more on Wikipedia.
